title: Old-School Playground
description: How well do you remember the games and activities from the schoolyard?

questions.question: In the game of marbles, what was the large marble used to shoot at other marbles called?
questions.explanation: The shooter (also called a 'taw') was the larger marble players used to knock other marbles out of the ring. Marbles was one of the most popular playground games from the 1940s through the 1960s.

questions.question: What playground game involved bouncing a small rubber ball while picking up small metal pieces?
questions.explanation: Jacks (or jackstones) required bouncing a small ball and scooping up an increasing number of small metal jacks before catching the ball. It was a favorite recess game, especially among girls.

questions.question: In the jump rope rhyme 'Cinderella, dressed in yella,' what did Cinderella go upstairs to do?
questions.explanation: The classic jump rope rhyme went: 'Cinderella, dressed in yella, went upstairs to kiss a fella. Made a mistake and kissed a snake. How many doctors did it take?' Then children counted jumps.

questions.question: What was the name of the schoolyard game where one person was 'It' and had to tag others who then became frozen?
questions.explanation: Freeze Tag was a variation of regular tag where tagged players had to freeze in place until another free player tagged them to unfreeze them. The game ended when all players were frozen.

questions.question: In the schoolyard rhyme game 'Miss Mary Mack,' what was she dressed in?
questions.explanation: 'Miss Mary Mack, Mack, Mack, all dressed in black, black, black, with silver buttons, buttons, buttons, all down her back, back, back.' This hand-clapping rhyme has been a playground favorite for generations.

questions.question: What schoolyard game involved hitting a small pointed stick into the air with a larger stick?
questions.explanation: Peggy (also called Tipcat) was a classic street game where players used a large stick to hit a smaller sharpened stick (the 'peg') into the air and then hit it as far as possible, similar to cricket or baseball.

questions.question: Which playground game required drawing numbered squares on the ground and tossing a stone?
questions.explanation: Hopscotch involved tossing a stone into numbered squares drawn on the ground, then hopping through the pattern on one foot to retrieve it. Different regions had their own variations of the layout.

questions.question: What was the name of the game where players formed a chain by linking arms and trying to break through another team's chain?
questions.explanation: Red Rover had two teams standing in lines holding hands. One team would call 'Red Rover, Red Rover, send [name] right over!' and that player would run and try to break through the opposing team's chain.

questions.question: In the choosing game 'Eeny, meeny, miny, moe,' what did you catch by the toe in the original schoolyard version popular in the 1950s?
questions.explanation: The widely known version goes 'Eeny, meeny, miny, moe, catch a tiger by the toe.' This counting-out rhyme was used by children to fairly select who would be 'It' in various playground games.

questions.question: What playground equipment consisted of a long plank balanced on a central pivot?
questions.explanation: The seesaw (or teeter-totter) was a playground staple for decades. Two children sat on opposite ends and alternately went up and down. Many have been removed from modern playgrounds due to safety concerns.

questions.question: Which schoolyard game involved throwing a ball against a wall and performing actions before catching it?
questions.explanation: Sevensies (also called Sevens) was a ball game where players threw a ball against a wall and had to complete a series of increasingly difficult actions (clapping, spinning, touching the ground) before catching it.

questions.question: What game, popular on city sidewalks, used a Spalding rubber ball bounced off front steps?
questions.explanation: Stoopball was hugely popular in urban neighborhoods, especially in New York City. Players threw a Spalding (or 'Spaldeen') rubber ball against the stoop steps and earned points based on how far it bounced back.

questions.question: In the game of Chinese Jump Rope, what was the elastic band typically made of?
questions.explanation: Chinese Jump Rope (also called Elastics) used a long loop of linked rubber bands stretched between two players' ankles. The jumper performed increasingly complex patterns as the band was raised higher.

questions.question: What game involved one player hiding their eyes and counting to 100 while others hid?
questions.explanation: Hide and Seek is one of the oldest and most universal children's games. The seeker counted at 'home base' while others hid, then called 'Ready or not, here I come!' before searching.

questions.question: Which playground game combined Hide and Seek with an element where the hidden person could 'free' others by kicking an object?
questions.explanation: Kick the Can combined elements of tag, hide and seek, and capture the flag. A 'can' was placed in the open, and hidden players tried to kick it before being tagged, which freed all captured players.
